segment.source: description: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to an already defined resource.
segment.target: description: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to an already defined resource.

segment.source: Resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a StaticResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: Resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a StaticResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: title: {StaticResource} markup extension'
segment.target: title: {StaticResource} markup extension'

segment.source: {StaticResource} markup extension
segment.target: {StaticResource} markup extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to an already defined resource.
segment.target: Provides a value for any XAML attribute by evaluating a reference to an already defined resource.

segment.source: Resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a StaticResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: Resources are defined in a ResourceDictionary, and a StaticResource usage references the key of that resource in the ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: key
segment.target: key

segment.source: The key for the requested resource.
segment.target: The key for the requested resource.

segment.source: This key is initially assigned by the ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: This key is initially assigned by the ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: A resource key can be any string defined in the XamlName Grammar.
segment.target: A resource key can be any string defined in the XamlName Grammar.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: StaticResource is a technique for obtaining values for a XAML attribute that are defined elsewhere in a XAML resource dictionary.
segment.target: StaticResource is a technique for obtaining values for a XAML attribute that are defined elsewhere in a XAML resource dictionary.

segment.source: Values might be placed in a resource dictionary because they are intended to be shared by multiple property values, or because a XAML resource dictionary is used as a XAML packaging or factoring technique.
segment.target: Values might be placed in a resource dictionary because they are intended to be shared by multiple property values, or because a XAML resource dictionary is used as a XAML packaging or factoring technique.

segment.source: An example of a XAML packaging technique is the theme dictionary for a control.
segment.target: An example of a XAML packaging technique is the theme dictionary for a control.

segment.source: Another example is merged resource dictionaries used for resource fallback.
segment.target: Another example is merged resource dictionaries used for resource fallback.

segment.source: StaticResource takes one argument, which specifies the key for the requested resource.
segment.target: StaticResource takes one argument, which specifies the key for the requested resource.

segment.source: A resource key is always a string in Windows Runtime XAML.
segment.target: A resource key is always a string in Windows Runtime XAML.

segment.source: For more info on how the resource key is initially specified, see x:Key attribute.
segment.target: For more info on how the resource key is initially specified, see x:Key attribute.

segment.source: The rules by which a StaticResource resolves to an item in a resource dictionary are not described in this topic.
segment.target: The rules by which a StaticResource resolves to an item in a resource dictionary are not described in this topic.

segment.source: That depends on whether the reference and the resource both exist in a template, whether merged resource dictionaries are used, and so on.
segment.target: That depends on whether the reference and the resource both exist in a template, whether merged resource dictionaries are used, and so on.

segment.source: For more info on how to define resources and properly use a ResourceDictionary, including sample code, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.
segment.target: For more info on how to define resources and properly use a ResourceDictionary, including sample code, see ResourceDictionary and XAML resource references.

segment.source: A StaticResource must not attempt to make a forward reference to a resource that is defined lexically further within the XAML file.
segment.target: A StaticResource must not attempt to make a forward reference to a resource that is defined lexically further within the XAML file.

segment.source: Attempting to do so is not supported.
segment.target: Attempting to do so is not supported.

segment.source: Even if the forward reference doesn't fail, trying to make one carries a performance penalty.
segment.target: Even if the forward reference doesn't fail, trying to make one carries a performance penalty.

segment.source: For best results, adjust the composition of your resource dictionaries so that forward references are avoided.
segment.target: For best results, adjust the composition of your resource dictionaries so that forward references are avoided.

segment.source: Attempting to specify a StaticResource to a key that cannot resolve throws a XAML parse exception at run time.
segment.target: Attempting to specify a StaticResource to a key that cannot resolve throws a XAML parse exception at run time.

segment.source: Design tools may also offer warnings or errors.
segment.target: Design tools may also offer warnings or errors.

segment.source: In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for StaticResource functionality.
segment.target: In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for StaticResource functionality.

segment.source: StaticResource is exclusively for use in XAML.
segment.target: StaticResource is exclusively for use in XAML.

segment.source: The closest equivalent in code is to use the collection API of a ResourceDictionary, for example calling Contains or TryGetValue.
segment.target: The closest equivalent in code is to use the collection API of a ResourceDictionary, for example calling Contains or TryGetValue.

segment.source: {ThemeResource} markup extension is a similar markup extension that references named resources in another location.
segment.target: {ThemeResource} markup extension is a similar markup extension that references named resources in another location.

segment.source: The difference is that {ThemeResource} markup extension has the ability to return different resources depending on the system theme that's active.
segment.target: The difference is that {ThemeResource} markup extension has the ability to return different resources depending on the system theme that's active.

segment.source: For more info see {ThemeResource} markup extension.
segment.target: For more info see {ThemeResource} markup extension.

segment.source: StaticResource is a markup extension.
segment.target: StaticResource is a markup extension.

segment.source: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.
segment.target: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.

segment.source: All markup extensions in XAML use the "\{" and "\}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.
segment.target: All markup extensions in XAML use the "\{" and "\}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.

segment.source: An example {StaticResource} usage
segment.target: An example {StaticResource} usage

segment.source: This example XAML is taken from the XAML data binding sample.
segment.target: This example XAML is taken from the XAML data binding sample.

segment.source: This particular example creates an object that's backed by a custom class, and creates it as a resource in a ResourceDictionary.
segment.target: This particular example creates an object that's backed by a custom class, and creates it as a resource in a ResourceDictionary.

segment.source: To be a valid resource, this element must also have an x:Key attribute value.
segment.target: To be a valid resource, this element must also have an x:Key attribute value.

segment.source: The value of the attribute is set to "GradeConverter".
segment.target: The value of the attribute is set to "GradeConverter".

segment.source: The resource is then requested just a bit further into the XAML, where you see .
segment.target: The resource is then requested just a bit further into the XAML, where you see .

segment.source: Note how the {StaticResource} markup extension usage is setting a property of another markup extension {Binding} markup extension, so there's two nested markup extension usages here.
segment.target: Note how the {StaticResource} markup extension usage is setting a property of another markup extension {Binding} markup extension, so there's two nested markup extension usages here.

segment.source: The inner one is evaluated first, so that the resource is obtained first and can be used as a value.
segment.target: The inner one is evaluated first, so that the resource is obtained first and can be used as a value.

segment.source: This same example is also shown in {Binding} markup extension.
segment.target: This same example is also shown in {Binding} markup extension.

segment.source: Design-time tools support for the {StaticResource} markup extension
segment.target: Design-time tools support for the {StaticResource} markup extension

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 can include possible key values in the Microsoft IntelliSense dropdowns when you use the {StaticResource} markup extension in a XAML page.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 can include possible key values in the Microsoft IntelliSense dropdowns when you use the {StaticResource} markup extension in a XAML page.

segment.source: For example, as soon as you type "{StaticResource", any of the resource keys from the current lookup scope are displayed in the IntelliSense dropdowns.
segment.target: For example, as soon as you type "{StaticResource", any of the resource keys from the current lookup scope are displayed in the IntelliSense dropdowns.

segment.source: In addition to the typical resources you'd have at page level (FrameworkElement.Resources) and app level (Application.Resources), you also see XAML theme resources, and resources from any extensions your project is using.
segment.target: In addition to the typical resources you'd have at page level (FrameworkElement.Resources) and app level (Application.Resources), you also see XAML theme resources, and resources from any extensions your project is using.

segment.source: Once a resource key exists as part of any {StaticResource} usage, the Go To Definition (F12) feature can resolve that resource and show you the dictionary where it's defined.
segment.target: Once a resource key exists as part of any {StaticResource} usage, the Go To Definition (F12) feature can resolve that resource and show you the dictionary where it's defined.

segment.source: For the theme resources, this goes to generic.xaml for design time.
segment.target: For the theme resources, this goes to generic.xaml for design time.
